descriptionSet.description: Lord Vishnu with two goddesses sitting on the Anant Shaiya (snake-throne) in a calender poster from 1935 that advertises Sunlight soap.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Sunlight
text-en: Sunlight Soap
text-en: 1935
description-en: Lord Vishnu with two goddesses sitting on the Anant Shaiya (snake-throne) in a calender poster from 1935 that advertises Sunlight soap. (ac/sp)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: /20080502_0435.jpg

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Ravi Varma's designs, first mechanically reproduced in the period 1894-1906, retained wide circulation for decades, not only in the form of posters, but also as redeployed in advertisements and calendars, such as the depiction of Vishnu and his two wives. (Richard H. Davis) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Like other products, these advertisements on calenders invoked devotional and mythological imagery to sell soap. Gods and goddesses were their first models. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The connection between Hindu Gods and soap through the motif of pureness is evident. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The original design dates back to c. 1900. (sg)
